reviewText:
Early Access Review

*Don't think my hours on record means anything, as I just idled it for the cards

I have never played such a non-entity of a game before. Sure, there have been games that made me think certain developers should be legally withheld from making more games, but this, this makes me question the very core essence of a programs existence. It's not so much how?" it was made
date: but "why?" it was made. As in
recommended: why do I have to install this? Why isn't this just part of Steam as a feature? Or more accurately
hoursPlayed: why isn't this a free flash game on the internet? Oh wait
voteText: it is. In various fashions.\n\nWhat this game does isn't very unique. Typing and word learning games have been around maybe since they've had visual GUIs and an ability to input text in a computer (and earlier before that with things like Scrabble). Their biggest strides came in the 90's with Mavis Beacon
helpfulPercent: JumpStart Typing and even Mario himself.\n\nThen people got bored with just mastering their WPMs
votesHelpful: and thankfully SEGA fixed that with Typing of the Dead. As they realised there needs to be more of a goal to achieve
votesFunny: plenty of others have actually tried to be more edutainment rather than just stiff educational tools. They actually offer something
commentsCount: and if not some kind of engaging single player challenge
column17: like Words with Friends.\n\nAce of Words on the other hand
column18: has done nothing to further the cause of mastery of the english language. It's by no means a regression
column19: but trying to think of what this game actually does well enough to be considered a game worth playing... well
column20: there is none. You just... turn it on
column21: play it for 90 seconds and then you're done. Maybe you try it once more
column22: but climbing the leaderboard just isn't enough. There's no progression at all here. It doesn't even attempt to teach you new words.\n\nThis is one of the most forgettable games in my library
column23: and what you see is what you get. I can't imagine that there are people clamoring for something so no frills
column25:
as there are so many more games that would be better to play that actually get you involved.

Better word games on Steam:
Letter Quest: Grimm's Journey Remastered
A pseudo RPG where you learn new words and relearn the definitions of old ones. Collect gems and buy better weapons to make your words hurt more. Really fun progression system.

Typing of The Dead: Overkill
What better way to test your WPMs than when the only way to survive is to go faster? Must go faster.

Bookworm Series
An oldie
column26: but a goodie. Only problem is that they lack modern Steam support/features like the cloud or achievements. Still really quality titles.\n\nThis game just gives me an air of people that just didn't try hard enough. Like
column27: just because it was a game about words
column28: they only had to put in the minimal effort. They wanted to remain in their little box and tried to be as inoffensive as possible and be as uncreative as they could
column30: it's just for some lame educational game! I don't REALLY have to try!". To me
column31: a game being as inoffensive as possible is just as offensive as the worst games ever made. This game is as cynical as they come
column32: and it doesn't even have to say a word.\n\nThere was a time when something like Ace of Words would have been useful. That time was the late 1980's. Thankfully
column34: and so should you. To better games."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love word games. I love the premise of this one. But I don't love this. It's quite possibly the buggiest game I've played, which doesn't make much sense when you consider that it's basically just '97 wordArt with a clock, database, input and a couple of randomisation and check processes.

I don't like to be so critical of small ventures, and I bet I'd love it if I hadn't already suffered 100 crashes... including ones that stop you from playing for days!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've got quite a few hours into this game, and since I own it I play occasionally to complete the achievements, but it's nothing I'd recommend buying. A very basic game with a terrible dictionary that was previously free.

Most prominently, keystroke detection is too slow. You'll be typing away words like sates" and "sate" and "seats" and "seat" and their various permutations and possibly only get half of them due to the poor response time.

The GUI is utterly basic with only a handful of options/menu choices
date: and as a fan of GameHouse games like Text Twist this is pretty disappointing. You can only play
voteText: and there are no other modes besides timed play. Hint feature is unlocked after a certain percentage of words have been entered correctly and can be used an unlimited number of times to get enough words to unlock the next level.\n\nActually
helpfulPercent: the Hint feature is the best part about this game; the dictionary is so bad that you'll need it to move onto the next unnumbered level. Certain proper names and places like "Rosie" and "Paris" are in the dictionary
votesHelpful: but basic words like "err" and "oes" aren't. I'm not sure why "Tesla" is in this but "Kant" isn't.\n\nIf it's in a cheap Steam key bundle
votesTotal: you might as well pick it up. It drops trading cards and has some easy achievements. But this is not worth $3.99."

Cons:It gets old very quickly.
Climbing ranks is easy because there are very few people who play.
Simple interface. Could very well be a basic flash game.If you want an anagram puzzle, there is an abundance of free-to-play browser versions that are better designed and optimized. This being on sold on Steam at a cost is not entirely justified.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI have played numerous anagram/word search/etc. games, and this is probably the worst one ever.  The basic gist is similar to Word Whomp:  You're given a set of 8 letters and a time limit to spell as many words as you can.  There is a hint option which I did not use for the first couple of games.  When I did use it, I found that quite a few words that the game was looking for are not actual words, but rather intitalisms like IRS or SRS, suffixes like -ism, and other random letter combinations.  In short, save your money on this one.  I'm glad I got it for free.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAce of Words is a decidedly average spelling game. There's very little to the game, simply unscrambling words with different letters on each level. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAce of Words is pretty bad. It's a simple word jumble game, where players get a series of random letters and have to make words from them. The only impressive thing about this game is how it managed to screw this up, even with so simple and unoriginal a premise. Its dictionary is full of names, proper nouns, acronyms, and three-letter prefixes, but some words like True
date: which are actually...well...WORDS are nowhere to be found. I could tolerate this but for the fact that you need to guess a ridiculous number of words in order to move on to the next puzzle and keep playing. Pair the time limit with a game that expects you to come up with fistfuls of fictional words and you have a recipe for frustration. For some reason this game has been in Early Access for months, so there's still time for these issues to be resolved. As things are now, however, this is a hard one to recommend.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Though the concept is great, and it still remains a fun way to pass a few minutes of time, I cannot recommend this game due to a few fatal flaws. Despite being a word game, the the dictionary is missing MANY words. Not only that but many words are misspelled or just plain incorrect (catnep?).

Despite these flaws, the game is not completly ruined, and it is ambitous to include many languages, so I will give them that. Perhaps a later update will fix these problems, but untill then, you're better off pulling out the ol' sudoku board.

-A great game for free, but not worth the sale price when so deeply flawed.
-An indie game that doesn't have indie" in it's dictionary."

reviewText:
I am a big fan of puzzle games. I have spent many consecutive days playing similar games, such as Text/Word Twist.

This game as it stands now is buggy and there are many things the developers missed. Here are a few things I've notived:

1) As per usual, there are words missing that should be listed, but this is a frequent occurrence for games like these.
2) Once you complete a puzzle, the words you missed are never revealed.
3) The words are not listed alphabetically. It is nearly impossible to logic your way into completing the puzzle and to figure out which words you're missing.
4) I had to quit several times when I was unable to type any letters or click them to enter a new word.
5) There is no way to save your progress (as far as I can tell).

Unfortunately there are no good alternatives to this game on Steam, but if you're feeling an urge to play this, don't pay the $5 or play it for free online.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played this for a while because the achievments seemed easy to get and that 100% is always tempting. It was easy (a few hours) except for that last one (days and days). I'm sure someone who is a native english speaker (I am not) can do it a lot faster, but still, it was hell.

Lets be straight. This is crap. Really scraping the bottom of the barrel. It looks cheap, it plays cheap. There are some minor bugs, and some really strange words mixed in (names for example). Some obvious things has been censored out. And some obvious things are still in (like the N-word, had a laugh at that one, sorry).

But there is no game to be found here! This feels like the result of a Learn programming in 14 days!"-book. It's a lazy attempt at a game and it cannot hide behind the "early access" label at all. It should not be on steam.

Don't waste your time or money."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Update as of 11/16:

Dev isn't really responding to any of the concerns in the discussions and its been over a month since an update, which I can't tell what it did to be quite honest. No word outside of the last update either. Be wary of getting this game I'd say. 12/9 There was an update. The developers were apparently preoccuppied with another game release.

Original review:

Good word game. Dev says they will be fixing some of the things that were complained about by the community, which is always a plus. As of right now, you have to know some obscure words to unlock the hint function, but getting the hint function will almost always guarantee you getting to beat the level you're on.

As of right now, I'd probably not get this game until the developer releases the patch for it that does something about all of those obscure words.

Oh, and if you're wondering about my skill level in word games for me to claim a lot of words are obscure, I have mostly every word game on steam worth anything and I play alot of scrabble, ruzzle, words with friends and etc.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For the price tag it pretty much delivers what you pay for. Quite simple anagrams game. As people stated in other reviews not many people playing it right now but it might change depending if the devs add some variety and fix few issues here and there. Would recommend gifting it to your friends who are learning english or in need of some vocabulary practice.

It's enjoyable, easy achievements, has cards, won't take too much of your time, if you're into perfecting games this would take ten hours tops.

No idea where they sourced the words from but it needs some fixes, accepts some abbreviations, doesn't accept others. Same goes for names, singulars, plurals and even meaningful words. Considering it's still on early access, these issues are on an acceptable level and the game is far from unplayable or broken.
voteText: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After playing the game a bit now after the full release, I have run into far fewer issues than when I had written my original review. Good job Devs! I've only hit a few, infrequent words that I question whether or not they shoyuld be in the dictionary, but overal, there have been no surprises.

I like the ability to change modes from 6 to 8 letters, but even more options would be cool. Plus, this would add to the replayablility, trying to get into more top leaderboard spots. But with 6 and 8, there's still enough to work with. The essentially endless mode (assuming you can keep it up) is fun, and adds even more replayability as you try to get further (and get a higher score) than previous runs.

Sometimes hints are great and help you eek past the level continuation checkpoint, which is nice. Sometimes hints come a little early though, and while you can just not use them if you like, if you decide to, it really takes away from the challenge.

All in all, the game is fun, and it's good to pick up for short spurts, and the problems I found with the Early Access version have been fixed.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW BELOW:
So here's a revised take on an earlier review: The game still needs work, but this should be expected with an Early Access game. That being said, the dev is responsive to feedback and is actively making improvements, which is why I'm overall recommending this.

One of the biggest downsides for me is that the dictionary is not complete (i.e. ERRED is valid, yet ERR, which is the same word in a different form, is not). Arguably, it may never be complete, and some may argue that some words should be in the list, while others will disagree. Personally, I feel like the example above (along with others I found just like it) is a reasonable argument to make. I know it is very silly for a hugely popular game like Words With Friends to tell you the word OK" is not valid
date: while asking you to click "OK" to continue
hoursPlayed: disagreements over valid words happen in games like this.\n\nThe game concept is basic
voteText: don't expect any fancy art or a magical experience
helpfulPercent: but it kept me entertained well enough to play a number of rounds -- despite the dictionary issue
votesHelpful: and it is likely something I will come back to from time to time when I've got a few minutes to kill and don't want to get super involved in another game.\n\nFix the dictionary and you've got yourself a solid game."

reviewText:
(Got this game courtesy of ReviewExperts & Ocean Media LLC.)

Here's a $4 Word Scramble puzzle game that is really something you would expect for free from Facebook and it's missing words you could ordinarily think of on your own.  How much should this game be worth?
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=651982020

In terms of achievement grinding.  Yeah, there's grinding.  At the time of this writing, there is an achievement that requires 10,000 words.  Sure the game's fun, but after about 1500 words, you will feel tired.  For me, the anagram decoding got stuck in my head aand I began to scramble and descramble words in real life.  Messed up a few nights of sleep.


PROS:
+ Nice graphics
+ Nice interface
+ Still being updated thanks to user feedback

CONS:
- Buggy
- Repetitive
- Dictionary needs to be fixed
- Screws with the mind
- 17 second music loop that will eventually become irritating
- Devs are quick to mark reviews and delete Steam Discussion posts they do not agree with (Which is why it took me a while to edit this review)


If you REALLY want to buy this game, feel free.  I, however, cannot recommend this game in good faith.  I wish this developer the best of luck in his project.


2/10  A free game that costs $4 and has grindy achievements.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I guess the process of testing a game before launching it isn't something this company is aware of or cares about?

I tried to play but quit out of frustration since the game is missing many, many valid 3, 4, and 5 letter words.  I'm not talking about esoteric words, I mean simple things like: rob, rue, flu, false, drat, berm, roe and similar.  How can anybody play a word game like this?

Adding to this frustration is mouse clicks on the letter tiles that don't register about 20% of the time.

Want to take a shot at the leaderboards?  No chance as this game makes cheating trivial - just click the pause button and go look up the words on the anagram finders online.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

All you see in the pictures is all you get. You are given 8 random letters and you make words. That's it. There are much better games eather free or for similar amount of money (like Bookworm).
If you want all achievements, you have to make 10.000 words, so you will mostly end up using anagramer. That way the game changes to another simulator on the Steam market, this time Secretary Simulator". You just keep writting. Give it about solid 15 hours and you may complete it.
Also I find very funny that they want to add more languages
date: yet they have problems even with English (missing plural forms or commonly used words
recommended: yet the word "SPCA" is in the game).\nAvoid now
hoursPlayed: and probably avoid even after release
voteText: because I don't see a way how it could become fun."

reviewText:
Product received for free

My real time is ~10-11 hours since I used a program that idles for cards. I got Ace of Words" for free from a friend and it had been on my wishlist for about 1-2 weeks at that time. I really wanted to enjoy this game but that didn't happen.
I will list the things that I've found while playing it:

Pros:
- Has achievements and can be 100%-ed too but takes a while.
- Has trading cards.

Cons:
- The game is missing some words that can be added. Examples : Pee
voteText: Ado
column29:
Orc. It's odd because some of these words are added to the game's dictionary in their single or plural form but the other one isn't added.
- The music seems ok-ish at first but after a while you realise it's repetitive and eventually mute the game.
- I am glad the 10K-words achievment has been reduced to 5K but it's still grindy. I lost interest after 2K words so I was waiting for the moment when I hit 5K.
- Overpriced. Yep
column30:
sad but true. If you manage to get it for 1 euro that would be ok-ish price but if you really want this game   pay as less as you can. I don't regret playing it because I got it for free but If I had paid more than 1 euro I'd be angry right now.

Conclusion:
Avoid unless it's below 1 euro and you want to get another 100% game or some cards."
